Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Recent avalanche further north on same ridgeline. R2-D2-O, 1-2+ days old. 150' wide, 250' vertical. Looked to be snowbike triggered, and likely broke on the surface hoar layer, 1.5-2' deep. Some tracks crossed slope 150' below this pit which headed towards the avalanche, and appeared to be the trigger.
Just outside boundary rope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avg HS on NW-NE NTL 220-300", with leeward slopes >300". Numerous natural pinwheels and rollerballs below rock band features on South below 9500'. Upper elevation South also likely turned, expect MF crust to form overnight. Noted 2-4mm V on shaded terrain from last night's cold clear skies.
By the time of this pit, I stopped doing stability tests. The facets a foot or so above the ground aren't breaking in ECT's

ECTN18 down 32 on Dec 17th FC 2 CTE7(RP) down 11 on Jan 7th SH (SH not visible, decomposing and becoming a part of the snowpack) CTH21(SC)down 30 on Dec 17th FC 2 Weak Temp Gradient

Average HS on NW-NE NTL 220-260". Lees below ridgeline >300". Observed numerous natural pinwheels and rollerballs below rock bands on South aspect below 9500ft. Upper elevation South also likely turned, expect a melt freeze crust to form overnight on all South terrain. On shaded terrain noted 2-4mm V from last night's cold clear skies.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I skied from the pit location not from the top. There were 3 tracks from the top of Max's SW face. Having dug a hundred feet lower earlier in the week and having skied Max's from the top I thought the TD at a higher elevation would be deeper. The lower elevation pit dug earlier in the week was a meter deeper. A good example of spatial variability. A crust facet combo is still lingering.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile from HS-N-D3-R4-O that damaged houses in Aspendell on 20230109. Profile dug 110 feet from the crown for safety. Cross-loaded slope, making HS variable across slope and within profile. Structure at the actual crown was similar to the profile except that wind-packed layers where P had and much thicker: 110cm and 60cm.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug high on naughty girl, almost at the lookout.
The pit was dug on a ridge exposed to alternate wind scouring and wind loading. Depth was shallower than average for the area.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Nearby avalanche failed on a wind-loaded slope on the facet layer just below the crust at 104 cm. The crown was 1-2' deep and 100' wide. HS-U-R2-D2-O

Collapsing, localized; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This snow pit was dug as part of an AIARE Pro 1 class, in Leadville, CO. The objective was to observe structure of S aspect NTL, looking for instability.
Due to the Pencil hard slabs in the middle of the snowpack isolating columns was difficult and results were not exactly what we were predicting.
Dug to Dec 23rd interface (110cms), unreactive to tests performed

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pretty cohesive block all the way down to the 53cm layer. Was able to slide the huge slab off of this buried faceted layer.

OBJ: kartlägga Sz och bottenbägare.
Terräng: Myket vegetation i profilen. Storpåverkan på resultat. Lite snö i terrängen. För lite connectivity. Sz är inte ifyllda och uppnår inte D2, snarare D1.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: AIARE PRO1 Course, first time using snow pilot, test profile. ECT Note - ECT stepped up to 39cm interface at 33/90cm across column. One other pit in the area, same aspect and elevation, had a CT26 Q1-SP on this layer. PST cut length on 39cm interface added because it is required to submit the information.

HS-ASu-r3-D3-O
1000' vert, 1000' wide. Avg. crown depth 80-120cm, max 180 cm. Propagated another ~500-1000' around a west-facing slope and released another large avalanche on a north-facing slope.

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Only 1 redflag, unstable snow with the ECTP15 and CT12 SC pit result. ALPTRUTH score of 3, Path, Terrain trap, Unstable pit data. 2 ski cuts on the slope produced no results. Within ~50ft below our pit, the slope angle decreased to 30°.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Winds at 850mb S-X, SW with C-L conditions below ALP. Solar input from ~1215-1330 and frequent treebombing and pinwheeling out of tilted solar asps.
Rain crust at 95cm is breaking down and has hardness score of 4F, but is main layer of concern. 11/27 weak layer present @ 35cm but hard to effect.
